align-content-property.name: flex_context
align-content-property.summary: The CSS align-content property sets the distribution of space between and around content items along a flexbox's cross-axis or a grid's block axis.
align-content-property.title: align-content

align-content-property.name: grid_context
align-content-property.summary: The CSS align-content property sets the distribution of space between and around content items along a flexbox's cross-axis or a grid's block axis.
align-content-property.title: align-content

propdef-align-items.name: flex_context
propdef-align-items.summary: The CSS align-items property sets the align-self value on all direct children as a group.

chrome.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

chrome_android.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

firefox.notes: Multi-line flexbox has been supported since Firefox 28.

firefox_android.notes: Multi-line flexbox has been supported since Firefox 28.

ie.notes: In Internet Explorer 10 and 11, if column flex items have align-items: center; set on them and their content is too large, then they will overflow the bounds of their container. See Flexbug #2.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Samsung Internet 6.0.

webview_android.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

edge_blink.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

propdef-align-items.title: align-items

propdef-align-items.name: grid_context
propdef-align-items.summary: The CSS align-items property sets the align-self value on all direct children as a group.
propdef-align-items.title: align-items

propdef-align-self.name: flex_context
propdef-align-self.summary: The align-self CSS property overrides a grid or flex item's align-items value. In Grid, it aligns the item inside the grid area. In Flexbox, it aligns the item on the cross axis.

chrome.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

chrome_android.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 27, only single-line flexbox is supported.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 27, only single-line flexbox is supported.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Samsung Internet 6.0.

webview_android.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

edge_blink.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

propdef-align-self.title: align-self

propdef-align-self.name: grid_context
propdef-align-self.summary: The align-self CSS property overrides a grid or flex item's align-items value. In Grid, it aligns the item inside the grid area. In Flexbox, it aligns the item on the cross axis.

ie.notes: IE10 and 11 have the property -ms-grid-column-align which acts in a similar way to align-self.

propdef-align-self.title: align-self

flex-containers.name: display
flex-containers.summary: The display CSS property sets whether an element is treated as a block or inline element and the layout used for its children, such as flow layout, grid or flex.
flex-containers.title: display

propdef-flex-basis.name: flex-basis
propdef-flex-basis.summary: The flex-basis CSS property sets the initial main size of a flex item. It sets the size of the content box unless otherwise set with box-sizing.

firefox.notes: Since Firefox 28, multi-line flexbox is supported.

firefox_android.notes: Since Firefox 28, multi-line flexbox is supported.

ie.notes: When a non-auto flex-basis is specified, Internet Explorer 10 and 11 always uses a content-box box model to calculate the size of a flex item, even if box-sizing: border-box is applied to the element. See Flexbug #7 for more info.

propdef-flex-basis.title: flex-basis

flex-direction-property.name: flex-direction
flex-direction-property.summary: The flex-direction CSS property sets how flex items are placed in the flex container defining the main axis and the direction (normal or reversed).

notes: Since Firefox 28, multi-line flexbox is supported.
Does not support overflow when using *-reverse. See bug 1042151 for more info.
Since Firefox 28, multi-line flexbox is supported.
Does not support overflow when using *-reverse. See bug 1042151 for more info.

flex-direction-property.title: flex-direction

flex-flow-property.name: flex-flow
flex-flow-property.summary: The flex-flow CSS shorthand property specifies the direction of a flex container, as well as its wrapping behavior.
flex-flow-property.title: flex-flow

flex-grow-property.name: flex-grow
flex-grow-property.summary: The flex-grow CSS property sets the flex grow factor of a flex item main size.

firefox.notes: Since Firefox 28, multi-line flexbox is supported.

firefox_android.notes: Since Firefox 28, multi-line flexbox is supported.

flex-grow-property.title: flex-grow

flex-shrink-property.name: flex-shrink
flex-shrink-property.summary: The flex-shrink CSS property sets the flex shrink factor of a flex item. If the size of all flex items is larger than the flex container, items shrink to fit according to flex-shrink.

notes: Since Firefox 28, multi-line flexbox is supported.
Before Firefox 32, Firefox wasn't able to animate values starting or stopping at 0.
Since Firefox 28, multi-line flexbox is supported.
Before Firefox 32, Firefox wasn't able to animate values starting or stopping at 0.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer 10 uses 0 instead of 1 as the initial value for the flex-shrink property. A workaround is to always set an explicit value for flex-shrink. See Flexbug #6 for more info.

flex-shrink-property.title: flex-shrink

flex-wrap-property.name: flex-wrap
flex-wrap-property.summary: The flex-wrap CSS property sets whether flex items are forced onto one line or can wrap onto multiple lines. If wrapping is allowed, it sets the direction that lines are stacked.

ie.notes: Partial support due to large number of bugs present. See Flexbugs.

flex-wrap-property.title: flex-wrap

flex-property.name: flex
flex-property.summary: The flex CSS shorthand property sets how a flex item will grow or shrink to fit the space available in its flex container.

notes: Since Firefox 28, multi-line flexbox is supported.
Before Firefox 32, Firefox wasn't able to animate values starting or stopping at 0.
Until Firefox 61, flex items that are sized according to their content are sized using fit-content, not max-content.
Since Firefox 28, multi-line flexbox is supported.
Before Firefox 32, Firefox wasn't able to animate values starting or stopping at 0.
Until Firefox 61, flex items that are sized according to their content are sized using fit-content, not max-content.

Internet Explorer 11 ignores uses of calc() in the flex-basis part of the flex syntax. This can be worked around by using the longhand properties instead of the shorthand. See Flexbug #8 for more info.

Internet Explorer 11 considers a unitless value in the flex-basis part to be syntactically invalid (and will thus be ignored). A workaround is to always include a unit in the flex-basis part of the flex shorthand value. See Flexbug #4 for more info.

Internet Explorer 10 and 11 ignore uses of calc() in the flex-basis part of the flex syntax. This can be worked around by using the longhand properties instead of the shorthand. See Flexbug #8 for more info.

Internet Explorer 10 and 11 consider a unitless value in the flex-basis part to be syntactically invalid (and will thus be ignored). A workaround is to always include a unit in the flex-basis part of the flex shorthand value. See Flexbug #4 for more info.

flex-property.title: flex

propdef-justify-content.name: flex_context
propdef-justify-content.summary: The CSS justify-content property defines how the browser distributes space between and around content items along the main-axis of a flex container, and the inline axis of a grid container.

chrome.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

chrome_android.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 27, Firefox supported only single-line flexbox.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 27, Firefox supported only single-line flexbox.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

webview_android.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

edge_blink.notes: Older versions of the specification treat absolute positioned children as though they are a 0 by 0 flex item. Later specification versions take the children out of the flow and set their positions based on align and justify properties. Chrome implements the new behavior beginning with Chrome 52.

propdef-justify-content.title: justify-content

propdef-justify-content.name: grid_context
propdef-justify-content.summary: The CSS justify-content property defines how the browser distributes space between and around content items along the main-axis of a flex container, and the inline axis of a grid container.
propdef-justify-content.title: justify-content

item-margins.name: margin-left
item-margins.summary: The margin-left CSS property sets the margin area on the left side of an element. A positive value places it farther from its neighbors, while a negative value places it closer.
item-margins.title: margin-left

item-margins.name: margin-right
item-margins.summary: The margin-right CSS property sets the margin area on the right side of an element. A positive value places it farther from its neighbors, while a negative value places it closer.
item-margins.title: margin-right

min-size-auto.name: min-width
min-size-auto.summary: The min-width CSS property sets the minimum width of an element. It prevents the used value of the width property from becoming smaller than the value specified for min-width.

firefox.notes: CSS 2.1 leaves the behavior of min-width with table undefined. Firefox supports applying min-width to table elements.

firefox_android.notes: CSS 2.1 leaves the behavior of min-width with table undefined. Firefox supports applying min-width to table elements.

opera.notes: CSS 2.1 leaves the behavior of min-width with table undefined. Opera supports applying min-width to table elements.

min-size-auto.title: min-width

order-property.name: order
order-property.summary: The order CSS property sets the order to lay out an item in a flex or grid container. Items in a container are sorted by ascending order value and then by their source code order.

firefox.notes: Since Firefox 28, multi-line flexbox is supported.

firefox_android.notes: Since Firefox 28, multi-line flexbox is supported.

order-property.title: order

visibility-collapse.name: visibility
visibility-collapse.summary: The visibility CSS property shows or hides an element without changing the layout of a document. The property can also hide rows or columns in a <table>.

notes: Internet Explorer doesn't support visibility: initial.
Up to Internet Explorer 7, descendants of hidden elements will still be invisible even if they have visibility set to visible.

visibility-collapse.title: visibility
